items.title: Navigating the Gig Economy: My Journey Through Rideshare and Delivery Platforms
items.author: Brad
items.description:
I’m Bradley Wood, an entrepreneur and developer who has spent considerable time navigating the gig economy. My journey began in the East Central Indiana area, driving for Uber and occasionally venturing into Indianapolis. Here are some of the insights and strategies I’ve gathered along the way.

Uber and Lyft: Finding the Right Spots

Become a Lyft Driver

Driving in Indianapolis during a Colts game, I discovered the importance of positioning. I shuttled passengers between Lucas Oil Stadium and areas like Broad Ripple and Fishers, learning to anticipate where rides would be in demand. Back in Richmond, a smaller and less populated area, I used the rider app to locate other cars and strategically positioned myself near bars and hotels to maximize ride requests.

Instacart: Making the Most of Grocery Runs

For Instacart, I learned the value of being selective with orders. Some stores, like ALDI, were challenging due to unlabeled aisles, so I often prioritized shopping at Meijer, where I could also use my mPerks account to earn rewards. A helpful tip I picked up for grocery shopping: use the water from vegetables to moisten your fingers and open those tricky produce bags more easily. Small adjustments like these make a big difference when time is money.

DoorDash: Maximizing Efficiency and Opportunities

On DoorDash, I realized how important it was to have the right equipment. Investing in a pizza delivery bag early on allowed me to access more orders and improve my customer satisfaction. I also kept my car key on a separate keychain for quick access and used my vehicle’s drink holders to stabilize beverages during delivery. These small practices helped me stay efficient and professional.

Final Thoughts

Navigating the gig economy in smaller towns like Richmond comes with its own set of challenges, but also unique opportunities. Adapting to the local environment and being resourceful with tools and strategies made all the difference. Whether it was positioning myself strategically for rides, being selective with grocery orders, or equipping myself for specialized deliveries, I found that versatility and proactivity were key.

The gig economy isn’t just about driving or delivering — it’s about learning to anticipate needs, working smarter, and making the most of your environment. If you’re considering gig work, especially in a smaller area, I hope these insights help you hit the ground running.

items.title: Building an Advanced DNS Lookup Tool: A Step-by-Step Guide
items.author: Brad
items.description:
Introduction:

DNS (Domain Name System) is the backbone of the internet, translating domain names into IP addresses. Whether you’re a developer troubleshooting domain issues or a curious tech enthusiast, having a DNS lookup tool at your fingertips can be incredibly valuable. At dns-lookup.bradwood.dev, we built an advanced DNS lookup tool to make this process seamless. In this blog post, I’ll guide you through creating a similar tool, including its features, code implementation, and best practices.

Features of the DNS Lookup Tool

  • Flexible Record Lookup: Supports multiple DNS record types (A, AAAA, MX, NS, etc.).
  • User-Friendly Interface: Input domain name and record type, then view results.
  • History Management: Save, load, and clear lookup history.
  • Dark/Light Mode: Switch between modes for comfortable usage.
  • Save to File: Export lookup history for future reference.

Technology Stack

  • Frontend: HTML, CSS (Bootstrap), and JavaScript.
  • Backend Service: Google Public DNS API for querying DNS records.

Code Implementation

1. Basic HTML Structure

The HTML defines the layout for inputs, results, and history:

<div class="container bg-light p-4 rounded">
  <h1 id="title">Advanced DNS Lookup Tool</h1>
  <input type="text" id="domainInput" placeholder="Enter domain name">
  <select id="recordType">
    <option value="A">A</option>
    <option value="AAAA">AAAA</option>
    <option value="MX">MX</option>
    <option value="NS">NS</option>
    <option value="TXT">TXT</option>
  </select>
  <button onclick="lookupDNS()">Lookup DNS</button>
  <button onclick="loadHistory()">Load History</button>
  <button onclick="clearHistory()">Clear History</button>
  <button onclick="saveHistoryToFile()">Save to File</button>
  <div id="loading" style="display:none;">Loading...</div>
  <div id="result"></div>
  <div id="history"></div>
</div>

2. JavaScript for Core Functionality

The JavaScript handles the DNS lookup process, integrates with the Google DNS API, and manages user interaction.

DNS Lookup Function:

async function lookupDNS() {
  const domain = document.getElementById('domainInput').value;
  const recordType = document.getElementById('recordType').value;
  const loadingDiv = document.getElementById('loading');
  const resultDiv = document.getElementById('result');

  if (!domain) {
    alert("Please enter a domain name");
    return;
  }
  loadingDiv.style.display = 'block';
  resultDiv.innerHTML = "";
  try {
    const response = await fetch(`https://dns.google.com/resolve?name=${domain}&type=${recordType}`);
    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new Error('Failed to fetch DNS records');
    }
    const data = await response.json();
    loadingDiv.style.display = 'none';
    if (data && data.Answer) {
      let resultHTML = "";
      data.Answer.forEach(record => {
        resultHTML += `<p>Type: ${record.type}, TTL: ${record.TTL}, Data: ${record.data}</p>`;
      });
      resultDiv.innerHTML = resultHTML;
      saveToLocalStorage(domain, recordType, resultHTML);
    } else {
      resultDiv.innerHTML = "No DNS records found.";
    }
  } catch (error) {
    loadingDiv.style.display = 'none';
    resultDiv.innerText = `Error: ${error.message}`;
  }
}

History Management:

function saveToLocalStorage(domain, recordType, result) {
  const history = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('dnsHistory')) || [];
  history.push({ domain, recordType, result, date: new Date().toISOString() });
  localStorage.setItem('dnsHistory', JSON.stringify(history));
}
function loadHistory() {
  const history = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('dnsHistory')) || [];
  const historyDiv = document.getElementById('history');
  historyDiv.innerHTML = "<h3>Lookup History</h3>";
  if (history.length === 0) {
    historyDiv.innerHTML += "<p>No history available.</p>";
    return;
  }
  history.forEach(item => {
    historyDiv.innerHTML += `<p>Domain: ${item.domain}, Type: ${item.recordType}, Date: ${new Date(item.date).toLocaleString()}<br>Result: ${item.result}</p><hr>`;
  });
}
function clearHistory() {
  localStorage.removeItem('dnsHistory');
  document.getElementById('history').innerHTML = "History cleared.";
}

3. Dark/Light Mode Toggle

const toggleModeBtn = document.getElementById('toggle-mode-btn');
const body = document.getElementById('body');

toggleModeBtn.addEventListener('click', function() {
  body.classList.toggle('dark-mode');
  if (body.classList.contains('dark-mode')) {
    toggleModeBtn.textContent = 'Switch to Light Mode';
  } else {
    toggleModeBtn.textContent = 'Switch to Dark Mode';
  }
});

4. CSS for Styling

body {
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  background-color: #f0f0f0;
}
.dark-mode {
  background-color: #121212;
  color: #ffffff;
}
.container {
  width: 600px;
  padding: 20px;
  background: #fff;
  border-radius: 10px;
}
button {
  margin: 5px;
}

How to Deploy the Tool

  1. Host the HTML File: Use platforms like GitHub Pages or Vercel to serve the HTML and JavaScript files.
  2. Integrate Analytics: Use Google Tag Manager (as shown in the code) for insights on user interaction.
  3. Set Up a Custom Domain: Point a subdomain (e.g., dns-lookup.bradwood.dev) to your hosting platform.

Enhancements to Explore

  • Rate Limiting: Avoid overloading the DNS API.
  • Custom Backend: Replace the Google DNS API with a self-hosted solution for more control.
  • Advanced Analysis: Display additional DNS details like SOA and SRV records.

Conclusion

Building a DNS lookup tool is an excellent way to understand web technologies and DNS fundamentals. By integrating modern features like dark mode, history management, and flexible DNS queries, you can create a professional-grade tool that’s both educational and practical.

Explore the live tool at dns-lookup.bradwood.dev and customize it further for your needs!

items.title: Unlock the Power of Financial Planning with the Free Finance Calculator
items.author: Brad
items.description:
Unlock the Power of Financial Planning with the Free Finance Calculator

Introduction

Financial planning can often feel overwhelming, but having the right tools at your disposal can make all the difference. Whether you’re a student, an investor, or someone just looking to manage personal finances more effectively, a solid financial calculator is essential. At BradWood.dev, we’ve developed a free financial calculator to simplify financial decision-making. In this blog post, we’ll explore how this finance calculator works, the types of calculations it performs, and how it can benefit you. Read on to learn how to make informed choices about your financial future, effortlessly.

Why Use a Financial Calculator?

A financial calculator is a powerful tool for anyone involved in managing or understanding money, investments, loans, or savings. Unlike traditional calculators, financial calculators can tackle complex financial calculations that would otherwise require time-consuming manual computations.

The Financial Calculator is designed to help with a wide variety of personal and business finance-related calculations. It includes everything from interest rate computations to future value assessments, making it suitable for everyone — students, mortgage seekers, business owners, or investors alike.

Key Features of the Financial Calculator

The free financial calculator on finance-calculator.bradwood.dev is more than just a calculator; it’s a comprehensive financial planning assistant. Here are the key features:

Time Value of Money (TVM) Calculations

  • The calculator helps assess the present value (PV) or future value (FV) of investments or loans, considering variables like the interest rate (I/Y), the number of periods (N), and periodic payments (PMT).
  • This feature allows you to calculate how much an investment will be worth in the future or what your initial investment would need to be today to reach a financial goal later.

Interest Rate (I/Y) Calculations

  • Unsure of the interest rate needed to achieve your investment goals? The calculator enables you to compute the required interest rate (I/Y) if you know your future goal, current investment, and the number of compounding periods.

Loan and Mortgage Calculations

  • The financial calculator can be used to determine the monthly payments (PMT) for mortgages, car loans, or other types of financing.
  • You can quickly determine how much you would need to pay monthly based on the principal loan amount, the interest rate, and the loan term.

Investment Planning

  • Whether you are saving for retirement or any significant financial goal, the future value (FV) feature helps estimate how much your current savings will grow.
  • It factors in contributions and compounding, giving you a realistic understanding of what your investments could yield over time.

How to Use the Financial Calculator

The Financial Calculator is simple and intuitive to use:

  1. N (Number of Periods): Input the number of periods over which your money will be invested or borrowed. For example, if you are taking out a 30-year mortgage, your N would be 360 (30 years × 12 months).
  2. I/Y (Interest Rate Per Year): Enter the interest rate for your investment or loan. This rate should be expressed as a percentage, such as 5 for 5%.
  3. PV (Present Value): This is the current value of an investment or the amount you are borrowing. For a loan, the present value is the principal amount borrowed.
  4. PMT (Payment): For monthly payments, enter the fixed payment amount here — commonly used in mortgage or auto loan calculations.
  5. FV (Future Value): Enter your desired future value. If you are calculating an investment’s future worth, this field will be your goal value.
  6. CPT (Compute): Click the CPT button after entering all the known values to solve for the unknown.

Real-World Applications of the Financial Calculator

  • Mortgage Planning: Suppose you’re interested in buying a new home. Using the financial calculator, you can determine your monthly mortgage payments based on the home price, the down payment, the interest rate, and the loan term. This enables you to make informed decisions before making such a significant financial commitment.
  • Investment Growth Projections: If you are thinking about investing in a retirement account or a savings plan, you can use the calculator to estimate how much your initial contributions will grow over time. Simply input your present value, interest rate, and time horizon to get an idea of your investment’s future worth.
  • Car Loan Payments: Planning to buy a car? The calculator can help you understand how much your monthly payment will be based on the car loan’s terms. By adjusting variables like interest rate and loan length, you can quickly compare different loan options to determine which is best for your budget.
  • Comparing Loan Offers: Use the calculator to compare different loan offers by entering various interest rates and terms. This way, you’ll have a clear view of which loan is the most cost-effective for you.
  • Take Control of Your Financial Future

The free financial calculator from BradWood.dev is a versatile tool that can assist you in making sound financial decisions — from calculating mortgage payments to planning your investment growth. By taking advantage of the powerful features of this calculator, you can simplify the complexities of personal finance and take control of your financial future.

Get started today by visiting http://finance-calculator.bradwood.dev and see how easy it is to plan and grow your financial goals. Make informed decisions, achieve financial wellness, and unlock the true potential of your finances!

Do you have questions or need help using the calculator? Feel free to reach out — we’re here to help!

items.title: Building a Free Pomodoro Timer: Boost Focus and Productivity
items.author: Brad
items.description:
The Pomodoro Technique is a proven time management strategy that breaks work into focused intervals, typically 25 minutes long, separated by short breaks. Inspired by its simplicity and effectiveness, I decided to build a Pomodoro Timer as a web-based productivity tool. In this blog post, I’ll walk you through the principles behind the technique, my thought process, and the steps I took to develop this app.

What is the Pomodoro Technique?

The Pomodoro Technique, developed by Francesco Cirillo in the late 1980s, is designed to enhance productivity and maintain focus. Here’s how it works:

  1. Set a Timer: Choose a task and set a timer for 25 minutes (one Pomodoro).
  2. Work Without Distractions: Focus entirely on the task during this interval.
  3. Take a Short Break: After 25 minutes, take a 5-minute break to recharge.
  4. Repeat: After completing four Pomodoros, take a longer break of 15–30 minutes.

This method helps prevent burnout and trains your brain to concentrate better over time. I wanted to create a web-based version that’s easy to use, customizable, and accessible for free.

Features of My Pomodoro Timer

The tool includes the following features:

  1. Customizable Durations: Users can set their preferred work and break durations.
  2. Pause and Resume: Allows for interruptions without losing progress.
  3. Visual Timer: Displays the countdown for easy tracking.
  4. Audio Alerts: Plays a sound when the timer ends, signaling a break or work session.
  5. State Persistence: Saves the timer state in localStorage so users can resume where they left off.

Tech Stack and Tools

  • Frontend: HTML, CSS (with Bootstrap for styling), and JavaScript.
  • State Persistence: localStorage for saving and retrieving timer state.
  • Deployment: Hosted on my custom domain, ensuring accessibility across devices.

Building the Pomodoro Timer: Step by Step

1. HTML Structure

The HTML layout provides the framework for the app. It includes:

  • Timer Display: Shows the countdown in minutes and seconds.
  • Controls: Buttons for starting, pausing, and resetting the timer.
  • Custom Settings: Inputs for setting work and break durations.

Here’s the structure:

<div class="container my-5">
  <h1 class="text-center mb-4">Pomodoro Timer</h1>
  <div class="timer text-center">
    <span id="minutes">25</span>:<span id="seconds">00</span>
  </div>
  <div class="controls text-center my-3">
    <button id="start" class="btn btn-success">Start</button>
    <button id="pause" class="btn btn-warning">Pause</button>
    <button id="reset" class="btn btn-danger">Reset</button>
  </div>
  <div class="settings text-center">
    <label>
      Work Duration (minutes):
      <input type="number" id="workDuration" value="25" min="1" max="60" class="form-control d-inline-block w-auto">
    </label>
    <label>
      Break Duration (minutes):
      <input type="number" id="breakDuration" value="5" min="1" max="30" class="form-control d-inline-block w-auto">
    </label>
  </div>
</div>

2. JavaScript Timer Logic

The timer functionality is implemented in JavaScript. Here are the key components:

Starting the Timer

window.addEventListener('load', () => {

    // Restore timer state
  }

Challenges and Lessons Learned

  3. State Persistence: Implementing localStorage taught me the importance of retaining user data for a seamless experience.

Future Enhancements

  1. Long Breaks: Add an option for longer breaks after a set number of Pomodoros.
  2. Progress Tracking: Provide analytics on completed Pomodoros to help users visualize their productivity.
  3. Mobile App Integration: Expand the tool into a mobile app for greater accessibility.

Conclusion

Building the Pomodoro Timer was a rewarding experience that combined time management principles with web development. The result is a functional and user-friendly tool that can help anyone enhance their productivity. I hope this blog post inspires you to build your own productivity tools and apply these principles to your projects.

If you’d like to try the timer or contribute to its development, visit pomodoro.bradwood.dev. Happy coding and productive Pomodoros!

items.title: Building an SEO Meta Tag Analyzer and Generator: A Developer’s Guide
items.author: Brad
items.description:
In today’s digital landscape, Search Engine Optimization (SEO) is vital for improving website visibility. Understanding and implementing meta tags correctly can significantly influence a site’s ranking and user engagement. In this blog post, I’ll walk you through how I built an SEO Meta Tag Analyzer & Generator, sharing insights on the thought process, technical implementation, and how this tool can help developers optimize their web projects.

Why Build an SEO Meta Tag Analyzer?

Before diving into the code, let’s address the “why.” Building an SEO Meta Tag Analyzer serves several purposes:

  1. Empowering Developers: Many developers struggle with optimizing SEO for their projects. This tool provides actionable insights into how meta tags can be improved.
  2. Streamlining SEO Processes: Instead of manually checking each tag, this analyzer automates the process, saving time and reducing errors.
  3. Learning Opportunity: Building this tool was an excellent way to practice JavaScript, DOM manipulation, and API interaction while solving a real-world problem.

Features of the Tool

Here are the features I implemented in the tool:

  1. Meta Tag Analysis: Extracts and evaluates key meta tags, including title, description, keywords, and Open Graph properties.
  2. Length Checks: Verifies the length of titles and descriptions to ensure compliance with SEO best practices.
  3. SEO Suggestions: Provides actionable suggestions for improvement.
  4. Meta Tag Generator: Generates well-structured meta tags based on the analyzed content.
  5. Copy-to-Clipboard Functionality: Allows users to easily copy the generated meta tags.

Tech Stack and Tools

  • Frontend: HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
  • API: Google Apps Script as a backend service to fetch and parse the HTML content of user-provided URLs.
  • Additional Libraries: DOMParser for parsing HTML and interacting with meta tags.

Key Implementation Steps

1. Setting Up the HTML Skeleton

The base HTML file provides the structure for the application. It includes:

  • A text input field for users to enter URLs.
  • Two buttons: one for analyzing meta tags and another for generating them.
  • A results section where analysis and suggestions are displayed.
<div class="container my-5">
  <h1 class="text-center">SEO Meta Tag Analyzer & Generator</h1>
  <div class="mb-3">
    <input type="text" id="urlInput" class="form-control" placeholder="Enter a URL to analyze" />
  </div>
  <div class="text-center">
    <button class="btn btn-primary" onclick="analyzeMetaTags()">Analyze</button>
    <button class="btn btn-success" onclick="generateMetaTags()">Generate Meta Tags</button>
  </div>
  <div id="results" class="mt-4"></div>
</div>

2. Analyzing Meta Tags with JavaScript

The analyzeMetaTags() function is the heart of the tool. It fetches the HTML content of a URL and parses it to extract meta tag information.

  • Fetching the HTML: Using fetch(), I retrieve the HTML content of the provided URL via a Google Apps Script API.
  • Parsing the HTML: The DOMParser parses the HTML string into a DOM object, allowing for seamless extraction of meta tags.
  • Evaluating Meta Tags: Each tag is checked for its presence and content. If a tag is missing, the tool provides feedback for improvement.
async function analyzeMetaTags() {
  const urlInput = document.getElementById("urlInput").value;
  const results = document.getElementById("results");
  results.innerHTML = ''; // Clear previous results
  if (!urlInput) {
    results.innerHTML = "<p>Please enter a valid URL.</p>";
    return;
  }
  try {
    const scriptUrl = `https://script.google.com/macros/s/.../exec?url=${encodeURIComponent(urlInput)}`;
    const response = await fetch(scriptUrl);
    const html = await response.text();
    const parser = new DOMParser();
    const doc = parser.parseFromString(html, "text/html");
    const title = doc.querySelector("title") ? doc.querySelector("title").innerText : "No title found";
    const metaDescription = doc.querySelector("meta[name='description']")?.getAttribute("content") || "No meta description found";
    const metaKeywords = doc.querySelector("meta[name='keywords']")?.getAttribute("content") || "No meta keywords found";
    results.innerHTML = `
      <p><strong>Title:</strong> ${title}</p>
      <p><strong>Meta Description:</strong> ${metaDescription}</p>
      <p><strong>Meta Keywords:</strong> ${metaKeywords}</p>
    `;
  } catch (error) {
    results.innerHTML = "<p>Failed to fetch the URL. Ensure it is valid and accessible.</p>";
    console.error(error);
  }
}

3. Generating Meta Tags Dynamically

The generateMetaTags() function creates meta tags based on user-provided or analyzed data. This function uses template literals to structure meta tags and displays them in the results section.

function generateMetaTags(title, description, keywords) {
  const generatedMetaTags = `
    <meta name="description" content="${description}">
    <meta name="keywords" content="${keywords}">
    <title>${title}</title>
  `;
  const results = document.getElementById("results");
  results.innerHTML = `
    <h3>Generated Meta Tags:</h3>
    <pre>${generatedMetaTags}</pre>
  `;
}

4. Adding User-Friendly Features

  • Copy-to-Clipboard: I implemented a function to allow users to copy the generated meta tags with a single click.
  • SEO Suggestions: Based on best practices, the tool suggests improvements, such as optimizing title and description lengths.

Challenges and Lessons Learned

  1. Cross-Origin Requests: Accessing the HTML content of external websites posed a challenge due to CORS policies. Using a Google Apps Script API as a proxy resolved this issue.
  2. Error Handling: Ensuring the tool gracefully handles invalid URLs or inaccessible content improved user experience.
  3. Scalability: While the tool works for basic analysis, future enhancements could include image alt-text analysis or keyword density checks.

Future Enhancements

Here are some ideas to expand the tool’s functionality:

  1. Bulk Analysis: Allow users to analyze multiple URLs simultaneously.
  2. Keyword Optimization Suggestions: Use machine learning or a predefined list of keywords to suggest improvements.
  3. Integration with CMSs: Provide plugins for platforms like WordPress or Shopify to automate meta tag generation.

Conclusion

Building the SEO Meta Tag Analyzer & Generator was a fulfilling project that combined my passion for development and SEO. It’s a versatile tool for developers looking to enhance their websites’ search engine visibility. By automating the analysis process and offering actionable insights, it bridges the gap between technical implementation and SEO best practices.

Whether you’re a beginner learning JavaScript or a seasoned developer seeking to refine your SEO workflows, I hope this blog post inspires you to create something impactful. Happy coding!

View the Tool in action at https://seo.bradwood.dev
